none: Letter to Louis L. McInnis from Austin A. Scott, March 17, 1882
Letter to Louis L. McInnis from Austin A. Scott, March 17, 1882
Box 1 Louis L. McInnis Papers/Box 1 Folder 11 Louis L. McInnis Papers

body.value:
[Header] [Image: Large building on the left] [Seal: Star with "OF" inside on the right] STATE AGRICULTURAL AND MECHANICAL COLLEGE College Station, March 17th 1882,

Dear Sir: at the
last meeting of the Austin
Literary Society I was in-
structed, as Corresponding
Secretary, to inform you of its un-
nanamous decision, requesting
You to deliver an address at
a Public Debate to occur on
Saturday Evening April 8th.
Please be so kind as to re-
ply in time (if convenient) for me
to report Your decision to the
Society, tomorrow evening,

Very respectfully submitted
Austin L Scott.

To L. L. McInnis
Prof. Math. A and M. College.

**Transcription and Analysis of Handwritten Letter**

Alright, let's break this down. I have a letter here, and my task is to produce a transcription, carefully noting all the details. We've got a letterhead that's pretty elaborate. The main part reads "**STATE AGRICULTURAL AND MECHANICAL COLLEGE**". Below that, we see "College Station," followed by a date, written, "March 17<sup>th</sup> 1882,". The "th" is superscript, and the "188" looks printed, while the "2" is handwritten.

Now to the main body. The salutation is "Dear Sir:". The text reads line by line:
"at the",
"last meeting of the Austin",
"Literary Society I was in-",
"structed, as Corresponding",
"Secretary, to inform <sup>you</sup> of its un-", (Here, there's an insertion, "inform you of")
"nanamous decision, requesting",
"you to deliver an address at",
"a Public Debate to occur on",
"Saturday Evening April 8<sup>th</sup>.",
"Please be so kind as to re-",
"ply in time (if convenient) for me",
"to report Your decision to the",
"Society, tomorrow evening,".

The closing is simple, "Very respectfully submitted".

The signature reads "Austin L Scott.".

Finally, the addressee information at the bottom left reads "To L. L. McInnis" and "Prof. Math. A and M. College.". Note that the second initial might look like 'P' or 'S' due to the cursive. However, the context of Louis L. McInnis, the Professor of Mathematics at the time, is strong.

I've checked the HTML allowed tags, and the formatting is quite detailed here to maintain accuracy. The "un-nanamous" on two lines is a misspelling that I will keep as it appears. I will represent the inserted "you" as superscript. I will also make sure to capitalize all proper nouns and maintain paragraph structure, putting the addressee and closing information with proper alignment. Let's see... everything seems in order.
